UNSEEN-open: UK February 2020 precipitation¶

In this project, the aim is to build an open, reproducible, and transferable workflow for UNSEEN – an increasingly popular method that exploits seasonal prediction systems to assess and anticipate climate extremes beyond the observed record. The approach uses pooled forecasts as plausible alternate realities. Instead of the ‘single realization’ of reality, pooled forecasts can be exploited to better assess the likelihood of infrequent events. We will illustrate the application for February 2020 precipitation, which was the highest on record in the UK: with what frequency of occurrence can February extreme precipitation events such as the 2020 event be expected?

Import packages¶

[1]:

##This is so variables get printed within jupyter

Download¶

We download the data from the Climate Data Store (CDS). For how to get started with CDS, see notebook 1.1 SetUp.

SEAS5¶

We will be using the SEAS5 hindcast, which is a dataset running from 1981-2016. The hindcast is initialized every month with 25 ensemble members and the forecast run for 6 months, indicated by blue horizontal bars below. February is forecasted by 6 initialization months (September-February). We discard the first month of the forecast because of dependence between the forecasts, explained in the evaluation section and are left with 5 initialization months (Sep-Jan) and 25 ensemble members forecasting February precipitation each year, totalling to an increase of 125 times the observed length.

For a summary of all available C3S seasonal hindcasts, their initialization months and more specifics, please see ECMWF page and the SEAS5 paper.

From CDS, we retrieve SEAS5 in notebook 1.2 Retrieve and concatenate the retrieved files in notebook 1.3 Merge. We create a netcdf file containing the dimensions lat, lon, time (35 years), number (25 ensembles) and leadtime (5 initialization months).

[6]:

SEAS5 = xr.open_dataset('../UK_example/SEAS5/SEAS5.nc')

E-OBS¶

EOBS can normally also be retrieved through CDS, as in notebook 1.2 Retrieve. Unfortunately, the product is temporally disabled for maintenance purposes. I downloaded EOBS (from 1950 - 2019) and the most recent EOBS data (2020) here.

The data has a daily timestep, so I resample the data into monthly average mm/day in notebook 1.3 Merge. I chose not to use the total monthly precipitation because of leap days. Finally I store a netcdf with only February precipitation, resulting in 71 values, one for each year within 1950 - 2020 over the European domain (25N-75N x 40W-75E).

[11]:

EOBS = xr.open_dataset('../UK_example/EOBS/EOBS.nc')
EOBS

The February 2020 anomaly¶

Here I illustrate how anomalous the February 2020 precipitation was across Europe based on EOBS.

I calculate the anomaly (deviation from the mean in mm/d) and divide this by the standard deviation to obtain the standardized anomalies.

[24]:

EOBS2020_anomaly = EOBS.sel(time = '2020')['rr'] - EOBS.sel(time = slice('1950','2019'))['rr'].mean('time')
EOBS2020_sd_anomaly = EOBS2020_anomaly/EOBS.sel(time = slice('1950','2019'))['rr'].std('time')

EOBS2020_sd_anomaly.attrs = {'long_name': 'Monthly precipitation standardized anomaly',
 'units': '-'}

EOBS2020_sd_anomaly

[27]:

ax = plt.axes(projection=ccrs.EuroPP())
EOBS2020_sd_anomaly.sel(time='2020-02').plot(transform=ccrs.PlateCarree(),
                                             robust=True,
                                             cmap=plt.cm.twilight_shifted_r,
                                             ax=ax)

ax.coastlines(resolution='110m')
ax.add_feature(cartopy.feature.BORDERS, linestyle=':')

gl = ax.gridlines(crs=ccrs.PlateCarree(),
                  draw_labels=False,
                  linewidth=1,
                  color='gray',
                  alpha=0.5,
                  linestyle='--')
gl.ylocator = mticker.FixedLocator([35, 45, 55, 65])

ax.set_title('February 2020')

# plt.savefig('graphs/February_2020_precipAnomaly.png', dpi=300)

[27]:

Text(0.5, 1.0, 'February 2020')

This graph shows that it has been very wet, with standardized anomalies > 2, for many parts of northwest Europe. Especially in the UK and the Netherlands we find large anomalies. We will first focus on UK precipitation, and assess how SEAS5 can be exploited to assess the frequency of occurrence of February extreme precipitation events such as the 2020 event.

Side note: in contrast to February, April has been very dry (I performed this analysis in May 2020) and I illustrated the large contrast in weather in this notebook.

UK masking¶

We create a mask for all 241 countries within Regionmask, that has predefined countries from Natural Earth datasets (shapefiles). We use the mask to go from gridded precipitation to country-averaged timeseries. We start with UK, number 31 within the country mask. For more on masking, see notebook 1.4 Mask.

[ ]:

SEAS5_UK_weighted = xr..open_dataset('Data/SEAS5_UK_weighted.nc')
EOBS_UK_weighted = .to_pandas().to_csv('Data/EOBS_UK_weighted.csv')
